conversation.content: So, um, the bill's $247.83 and there's basically twelve of us. Who's got a calculator?

Oh perfect, nothing says [frustrated] friendship like dividing an odd number by twelve people who ordered wildly different things— should we just split evenly and pretend Derek didn't order three appetizers?
Well, Derek also got the lobster. You know, the sixty dollar lobster.
Right, er, so Derek's basically looking at about ninety bucks honestly, while Sarah had a salad and water— this is why restaurants should just give everyone separate checks automatically.
Can we Venmo? Or is this a cash situation?
Half the table uses Venmo, three people only have Zelle, and grandpa brought exact change in coins— this is going to take longer than the actual meal did.
Wait, uh, who ordered the wine? I mean, that's another forty right there.
That was birthday girl's "gift" apparently, which means we're all splitting it except nobody told Marcus who doesn't drink— he's already doing the angry nostril flare thing.
Like, should we just throw credit cards in and sort of pray?
Credit card roulette! Except last time we did that, the server accidentally charged everything to one card and poor Jennifer's account got frozen for suspicious activity.
Hmm, didn't someone not tip last time? The thing is, I always overtip to compensate.
That was Brad, who insists ten percent is generous because "back in his day"— meanwhile our server is literally standing there watching us argue about quarters.
So, what if we actually just split evenly and call it a day?
Sure, let's penalize the vegetarians and reward the carnivores— Emma's already pulling up her itemized spreadsheet with color-coded cells for shared appetizers.
Emma has a spreadsheet? That's [trailing off] actually kind of brilliant...
She's [extremely happy] got formulas for tax distribution and everything— last month she invoiced us all with payment terms and a late fee structure!
Anyway, how much do I owe? I guess I had the pasta and one beer.
Twenty-three fifty for food, your beer's five, tax brings you to thirty-one, and if we're doing twenty percent tip— congratulations, you owe exactly thirty-seven dollars!
Perfect! Uhh, except I only have two twenties. Can anyone kind of break a twenty?
And here we go with the change-making chain reaction— by the time this is over, we'll all somehow owe each other money and the restaurant will have closed for the night.
